repnme.cdata!:
Lesotho - Phase 1B of the Highlands Water
            Project, and Community Development Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Phase 1B of the
            Highlands Water Project (HWP) in Lesotho were as follows:
            outcome was moderately satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was moderate; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory and borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Ratings for the Community Development Support
            Project were as follows: outcome was unsatisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was significant; Bank performance was
            highly unsatisfactory; and borrower performance was also
            highly unsatisfactory. Some of the lessons learned include:
            a successful construction program does not necessarily mean
            a successful development program. Attention is needed to the
            full objectives of a project, including "software"
            as well as "hardware." LHWP- 1B's successful
            water infrastructure program will be a main pillar in
            Lesotho's development program for decades to come. But
            the royalties did not go to poverty reduction, the
            project's most fundamental objective. Also, while
            LHWP-1B was strong in all aspects related directly to
            construction (engineering, physical works and water
            delivery), it performed weakly in software aspects (capacity
            building, training and resettlement). Lesotho and South
            Africa's "good practice" water treaty has
            features that may be relevant elsewhere. The following
            features have contributed to success: (i) clarity and detail
            in the treaty document, including procedures for adjusting
            to changing circumstances; (ii) appropriate institutions - a
            bridging institution has worked well in coordinating actions
            between the two countries; (iii) focused objectives; and
            (iv) independent dispute resolution mechanisms within the
            institutions themselves. The Bank's 20-year engagement
            providing technical and policy support, and as a motivator
            for the financial involvement of other lenders, also
            contributed to the treaty's success. Safeguards
            implementation should not be given second-tier priority, but
            should receive the same attention as the main project
            components. Successful implementation of a safeguard program
            requires the same design and supervision qualities as other
            project components.

12375205.trustfund:
TF024310-USTDP CONSULTANT TRUST FUND,TF030564-CANADA GENERAL CTF - FY04 -
            AFRICA (WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION),TF032947-AFRICA REGION - LAND RESEARCH MANAGEMENT,TF037780-LESOTHO - HIGHLANDS WATER I,TF040798-LESOTHO: HIGHLAND WATER,TF040906-LESOTHO: HIGHLANDS WATER PROJECT,TF050934-BNWPP-ENVIRONMENTAL FLOW ALLOCATION,TF029235-PHRD-POVERTY REDUCTION PROJECT,TF030571-IDA CONSULTANTS POOLED CTF - FY04,TF041047-LESOTHO - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT
            SUPPORT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Outcome
            is highly unsatisfactory, sustainability is highly unlikely,
            institutional development impact is negligible, and Bank
            performances is unsatisfactory while Borrower performance is
            highly unsatisfactory. Among the lessons learned were the
            following:  Without Government commitment, a small amount of
            money will not leverage a much larger amount of money.
            Aligning key Project documents is important; failure to
            harmonize the Project Appraisal Document (PAD) and the
            Development Credit Agreement (DCA) can lead to confusion
            during implementation and completion. Appropriate measures
            need to be taken, including the provision of necessary
            resources, as soon as deficits (such as failure to adhere to
            the Operational Manual) are identified, or once attainment
            of the development objectives became questionable. Given the
            stated importance of this Learning and Innovation Loan (LIL)
            to the lending scenario for Lesotho, insufficient Bank
            resources (both human and financial) were provided to ensure
            the appropriate support. Bank staff could avert problems,
            such as those experienced in this Project, at an earlier
            stage by paying closer attention to disconnects (unrealistic
            ratings) in Project Status Report ratings. Support for
            poverty monitoring may not be best placed in Community
            Demand-Driven (CDD) operations. Given the Bank's goal
            of poverty reduction, an appropriate mechanism, outside of
            CDD operations, for supporting the monitoring of poverty
            needs to be identified.

5084692.trustfund:
TF029235-PHRD-POVERTY REDUCTION PROJECT,TF030571-IDA CONSULTANTS POOLED CTF - FY04,TF041047-LESOTHO - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT
            SUPPORT PROJECT
5084692.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Rural development,Urban development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

abstracts.cdata!:
The Community Development Support
            Project aims to 1) test demand-driven and participatory
            approaches through a multi-sectoral special fund and draw
            lessons on how to support community development in Lesotho;
            and 2) test various mechanisms and tools to monitor poverty
            trends in Lesotho and coordinate national poverty monitoring
            and analysis activities. There are three project components.
            The first supports the establishment and implementation of
            the Lesotho Fund for Community Development (LFCD) by
            pre-testing LFCD operations and procedures in sub-projects
            in 22 pilot communities; setting up a basic set of
            operational and financial systems including an accounting
            and management information system; and financing all
            recurrent operational costs. The second component trains
            staff to build the capacity of LFCD and provides technical
            support to LFCD partner institutions such as community-based
            organizations, nongovernmental organizations, and private
            sector firms. The third component strengthens the
            capabilities of the Bureau of Statistics to collect,
            process, analyze, and disseminate data for poverty
            monitoring; and strengthens the quality of program
            monitoring and poverty analysis.
